page.title: 03COAST & LAND ROUND CRANTOCK
page.content: The River is called the Gannel and where it runs into the sea, across Crantock beach, is called an estuary. The sea floods the estuary twice a day creating salty marshes known as 'saltings'. The area surrounding the estuary is gently rolling landscape, mostly farmland or coastal heathland. A stream runs into the sea at Porth Joke beach and during the winter high tides and winds built up a sand bar which trapped the stream and created a lagoon. It was fairly shallow but now it has been made to drain away. The four headlands have high rocky cliffs (about 200 feet) which are nesting sites for many sea birds. The sea and wind have eroded the rocks and formed fascinating shapes and intriguing caves. The beaches shelve gently and have very fine grains of golden sand. The sand dunes are growing and moving.
